Student Council approves optional prOctoring system
The Student Council approved
the proposed optional proctoring
system by a 10-3 vote at its
Wednesday night meeting.
The system, which now awaits
only the approval of the
Academic Council, will be put to
student referendum early next
month.
The Council made minor
revisions in the document in an
effort to clarify certain
technicalities, and attached to
the proposal a disclaimer
reserving the right of "the
undergraduate student body,
through the Student Council, to
revert to an honor system by
referendum at any time."
Some SC members objected to
certain provisions of the loosely
structured system which, in the
words of SC President Andy
Savitz, are "necessarily vague so
that the spec ifics can be left up
to the ethics board, if and when
it is set up."
The proposal, formulated by a
special student-faculty panel

headed by Professor Owen
Phillips, Earth and Planetary
Sciences, calls for the institution
of a joint "ethics board" and
voluntary reporting of cheating.
Students and faculty members
are called on to participate in the
"maintenance of an atmosphere
of academic integrity at Johns
Hopkins." While the conduct of
examF is left entirely up to
faculty under the proposal,
students are expected to make
professors aware of any cheating
problem, not to necessarily
report offenders by name.
Some Council members
considered this stipulation too
lenient and called for its revision.
However, Honor Commission
Chairwoman Ann Connor, who
presented the system along with
other student members of the
joint committee, defended the
provision.
"We'd rather have students
report cheating without naming
names than have them not report
it at all," she told the Council.

"We want to encourage some
cooperation from students
because we're getting virtually
none now."
Other SC members expressed
concern that the system contains
no real process of appeal, since
students who are accused of
cheating must make a binding
decision on whether to accept
the "summary justice" of the
professor or bring the case to the
"ethics board," under the
proposal.

Safety equipment
may not be up to par
By JAY GOODGOLD
Safety equipment in certain
Chemistry labs in Remsen Hall
may not meet with state and
federal standards set down for
fire and injury prevention.
Students have expressed
concern about the emergency
lighting system in the building,
which failed during a blackout
last semester, and other problems
including plumbing leaks and a
faulty vacuum hood.
One student, who wished to
remain unidentified, asserted that
the emergency lighting system's
failure during the blackout
endangered those in the Organic
Laboratory at the time.
"When the blackout occurred,
Dr. Koreeda [Chemistry] raced
out of his office to make sure
that the kids in the lab weren't
killing themselves during the
darkness," the student said. "On
his way down the steps he almost
broke his neck because there was
no emergency lighting."
Federal regulation require that
all science buildings have
independently-operated lighting
systems which automatically
switch on when the regular
electrical system fails.
Dr. John Kopper, a member of
the Chemistry Department's
Safety Committee, admitted that
he was unaware that Remsen Hall
had no effective emergency

lighting until the blackout
occurred.
Recently, several universities
in California were fined for
failure to adhere to federal
sa fety standards. Over the past
few years, the National Safety
Council has instituted a new
series of safety regul ations for
science institutions. Gary Posner,
chairman of the Chemistry
Department's Safety Committee,
considers these standards a
burden to the University.
Although he believes the new
measures are important and
necessary, Posner stated that
private universities should not be
forced to bear the expense of
new safety equipment unaided.
"To put the entire financial
responsibility on the school's
laboratory safety equipment is
awful tough for academic
institutions, but not for private
scientific. Institutions," Posner
said.
Several years ago, the
Chemistry Department initiated a
series of safety .changes in the
department facilities.
Since then, fifty gallon drums
containing flammable liquids
have been moved into an
explosion-proof room, and
several thousand dollars has been
spent on new safety equipment,
including extinguishers, and fire
blankets.

Jones reveals what is up, Doc
BY GEORGE ZELINSKY
To the two generations Of
Americans for whom the nasal
intonation, "Neah, what's up,
Doc?" conjures up the image of a
lanky, grey rabbit with
Buckley-like teeth, twirling a
half-eaten carrot, "Chuck Jones"
was just another name flashing
by in the opening credits.
The creator of Bugs, and of
many other old-time Saturday
morning stalwarts like the
Roadrunner and Wily Coyote,
Porky Pig, Daffy Duck, and Pepe
Le Pew, Jones delivered a
technically informative and
anecdote-laden primer for
aspiring cartoonists and funnies
devotees in general.
Introduced by Hugh Kenner,
professor of English, as an
"old-timer of the medium,"
Jones told the small crowd that
he was distressed with the
direction cartoon-making is
taking.

The medium, Jones said, is
being taken over by
"commercialists" who are
primarily concerned with finding
a market rather than producing
well-crafted material. Pointing to
the low-budget shows poured

The Clinic operates under the
principle that "health care is a
right, not a privilege," and serves
approximately 7 500
Waverly-Charles Village residents
eacy year. Composed of more
than 100 professiona.1 and
non-professional volunteers, the
Clinic staff offers "general
medical care, gynecological
services, pediatrics, dental
services, early pregnancy
detection, and abortion
counseling and referral."
Since its inception, the Clinic
has slowly expanded its services
and now occupies three adjoining
rowhouses. Presently, the Clinic
is divided into two sections, one
for medical service, the other for
counseling.

Each time a patient comes to
the Clinic he is attended to by
the same "advocate" as the staff
strongly believes that "continuity
of care" is essential. The
advocate is responsible for the
general supervision of his patients
and it is he who "ties everything
together."
The Clinic, which is open four
nights a week (Monday through
Thursday, 6:30-10:30). has a
different staff for each night.
There is always one doctor in
attendence. along with nurses,
counselors, advocates, lab
technicians, and "behind the

The People's Free Medical Clinic
scenes" workers. Because of thie
arrangement, each staff forms an
identity and works closely with
each other. A unique facet of the
Clinic's spirit is the integration of
jobs and reponsibilities. For
example, if a nurse is not
available, a qualified member
with a different function of the
staff will substitute.
The counseling division of the
Clinic has two primary functions:
general counseling for emotional
and physical needs and -women's
counseling. People coming to the
clinic for counseling are dealt
with on a one to one basis and all

information taken by counselors
is kept confidential.
The counselors also give
pregnancy tests and offer
information about abortion and
venereal disease. The counseling
section is not limited to residents
of the Waverly—Charles Village
area,(unlike the medical service)
and will assist anyone in need.
Because the Clinic operates
under the premise that health
care should not be dependent on
a patient's ability to pay, funds
must be obtained from sources
other than patient fees. Much of
the Clinic's annual $30,000

budget is gotten from donations
and monthly pledges provided by
patients and members of the
community.
Apparently, however, the
Clinic's ties with Hopkins are not
as productive as they could be.,'
Many Hopkins students volunteer
to work at the Clinic, but they
usually don't commit themselves
for a long duration, according to
one worker there. The Clinic is
hesitant to treat Hopkins
students who seek medical
attention. The Clinic's staff
believes that students at Hopkins
should rely on the Brown
Infirmary for care, so as not to
deprive the community residents
who have nowhere else to go. In
situations where a_ student does
not receive adequate attention at
Brown Infirmary, the Clinic will
accept students as patients. For
example, Brown Infirmary will
not treat cases of venereal
disease, say the Clinic workers.
The People's Free Medical
Clinic is probably the most
significant exhibition of
community interaction in the
Waverly—Charles Village
neighborhood. Although growing
constantly, the Clinic needs more
doctors and contributions.
People interested in seeing how
the Clinic works are encouraged
to drop by weekday nights. And
everyone is invited to participate
in the upcoming week of
festivities which will begin next

may not be up to par
By JAY GOODGOLD
Safety equipment in certain
Chemistry labs in Remsen Hall
may not meet with state and
federal standards set down for
fire and injury prevention.
Students have expressed
concern about the emergency
lighting system in the building,
which failed during a blackout
last semester, and other problems
including plumbing leaks and a
faulty vacuum hood.
One student, who wished to
remain unidentified, asserted that
the emergency lighting system's
failure during the blackout
endangered those in the Organic
Laboratory at the time.
"When the blackout occurred,
Dr. Koreeda [Chemistry] raced
out of his office to make sure
that the kids in the lab weren't
killing themselves during the
darkness," the student said. "On
his way down the steps he almost
broke his neck because there was
no emergency lighting."
Federal regulation require that
all science buildings have
independently-operated lighting
systems which automatically
switch on when the regular
electrical system fails.
Dr. John Kopper, a member of
the Chemistry Department's
Safety Committee, admitted that
he was unaware that Remsen Hall
had no effective emergency

lighting until the blackout
occurred.
Recently, several universities
in California were fined for
failure to adhere to federal
sa fety standards. Over the past
few years, the National Safety
Council has instituted a new
series of safety regul ations for
science institutions. Gary Posner,
chairman of the Chemistry
Department's Safety Committee,
considers these standards a
burden to the University.
Although he believes the new
measures are important and
necessary, Posner stated that
private universities should not be
forced to bear the expense of
new safety equipment unaided.
"To put the entire financial
responsibility on the school's
laboratory safety equipment is
awful tough for academic
institutions, but not for private
scientific. Institutions," Posner
said.
Several years ago, the
Chemistry Department initiated a
series of safety .changes in the
department facilities.
Since then, fifty gallon drums
containing flammable liquids
have been moved into an
explosion-proof room, and
several thousand dollars has been
spent on new safety equipment,
including extinguishers, and fire
blankets.

The Clinic operates under the
principle that "health care is a
right, not a privilege," and serves
approximately 7 500
Waverly-Charles Village residents
eacy year. Composed of more
than 100 professiona.1 and
non-professional volunteers, the
Clinic staff offers "general
medical care, gynecological
services, pediatrics, dental
services, early pregnancy
detection, and abortion
counseling and referral."
Since its inception, the Clinic
has slowly expanded its services
and now occupies three adjoining
rowhouses. Presently, the Clinic
is divided into two sections, one
for medical service, the other for
counseling.

Each time a patient comes to
the Clinic he is attended to by
the same "advocate" as the staff
strongly believes that "continuity
of care" is essential. The
advocate is responsible for the
general supervision of his patients
and it is he who "ties everything
together."
The Clinic, which is open four
nights a week (Monday through
Thursday, 6:30-10:30). has a
different staff for each night.
There is always one doctor in
attendence. along with nurses,
counselors, advocates, lab
technicians, and "behind the

The People's Free Medical Clinic
scenes" workers. Because of thie
arrangement, each staff forms an
identity and works closely with
each other. A unique facet of the
Clinic's spirit is the integration of
jobs and reponsibilities. For
example, if a nurse is not
available, a qualified member
with a different function of the
staff will substitute.
The counseling division of the
Clinic has two primary functions:
general counseling for emotional
and physical needs and -women's
counseling. People coming to the
clinic for counseling are dealt
with on a one to one basis and all

information taken by counselors
is kept confidential.
The counselors also give
pregnancy tests and offer
information about abortion and
venereal disease. The counseling
section is not limited to residents
of the Waverly—Charles Village
area,(unlike the medical service)
and will assist anyone in need.
Because the Clinic operates
under the premise that health
care should not be dependent on
a patient's ability to pay, funds
must be obtained from sources
other than patient fees. Much of
the Clinic's annual $30,000

budget is gotten from donations
and monthly pledges provided by
patients and members of the
community.
Apparently, however, the
Clinic's ties with Hopkins are not
as productive as they could be.,'
Many Hopkins students volunteer
to work at the Clinic, but they
usually don't commit themselves
for a long duration, according to
one worker there. The Clinic is
hesitant to treat Hopkins
students who seek medical
attention. The Clinic's staff
believes that students at Hopkins
should rely on the Brown
Infirmary for care, so as not to
deprive the community residents
who have nowhere else to go. In
situations where a_ student does
not receive adequate attention at
Brown Infirmary, the Clinic will
accept students as patients. For
example, Brown Infirmary will
not treat cases of venereal
disease, say the Clinic workers.
The People's Free Medical
Clinic is probably the most
significant exhibition of
community interaction in the
Waverly—Charles Village
neighborhood. Although growing
constantly, the Clinic needs more
doctors and contributions.
People interested in seeing how
the Clinic works are encouraged
to drop by weekday nights. And
everyone is invited to participate

festivities which will begin next
week.
